text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page illustration occupying the upper two thirds of the folio, framed by a narrow fillet border; beneath, a single column of text begins with a large blue and gold ornamental initial set flush left. Generous outer and lower margins.

text_content.script_style: Gothic bastarda book hand, professional execution with regular letterforms, occasional flourishing and standard abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for the initial and small highlights; ultramarine and vermilion alternate on riders’ garments and horse trappings to denote rank; verdigris and lead white layered for vibrant green ground; white highlights applied atop pigments for modeling; overall palette well-preserved with minimal pigment loss.

features: Triangular grouping of mounted hunters at center
Diagonal thrust of spears and hunting horns
Receding landscape with distant castle and river
Overlapping horses and dogs to suggest depth
Horizontal band of green ground as unifying base

decorative_elements: Narrow fillet border in black ink
Stylized tree clusters forming natural border
Distant castle motif repeated left and right
Equestrian harness patterning in alternating colors

drawing_technique.line_style: Confident quill pen outlines in dark brown with varied line weight for figure contours and fine detailing
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle parallel hatching and white lead highlights on drapery and horse musculature
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping elements define receding space; no geometric perspective

content_theme.scene_description: A single hunting tableau depicts eight mounted noblemen and two foot huntsmen engaged in a boar hunt. Central riders wear richly decorated cotehardies in blue and red, mounted on horses caparisoned in matching tinctures. One huntsman on the right advances a long spear toward a dark boar, while hounds—six in pursuit—leap forward at the quarry. Two figures at upper left sound a curved horn, guiding the pack through a grove of stylized linden trees. In the background, rolling hills rise to two distant fortified towns by a river. The ground plane is rendered in a single green wash with horizontal ink rulings. The nobles wear brimmed hats, belts bearing hunting knives, and retainers hold spare spears. Each horse’s tack displays alternating blue and red geometric patterns edged in gold. The boar’s bristled form contrasts with the sighthounds’ sleek bodies. Spatially, the largest horses occupy the foreground, with smaller figures and animals behind. Costume details—tailored hose, pointed poulaines, fur-edged collars—identify social status. The composition emphasizes coordinated movement: spears and dogs converge on the boar, directing the viewer’s eye toward the central action.

secular: Noble huntsmen in blue and red cotehardies with matching hoods, carrying spears, mounted on caparisoned horses
Foot huntsmen in simpler doublets and hose, one blowing a hunting horn
Pack of sighthounds with collars, in active pursuit of the boar

objects: Long wooden hunting spears with iron heads
Horse saddles and bridles with alternating blue and red decoration
architectural: Distant castle on hill with square towers and crenellations
Secondary fortified town across a river
natural: Row of stylized linden trees with rounded canopies
Rolling grassy landscape with minimal terrain variation

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, very smooth surface with faint foliate hair-follicle pattern; folio from quaternion gathering, ruled in ink and plummet.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent; pigments retain high saturation, minor flaking of vermilion at page edge, slight cockling in extreme lower margin, evidence of 19th-century perimeter consolidation.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under initial leaf gold
Visible underdrawing in brown ink beneath paint layers
Fine engraver’s punchwork in gold initial background
Uniform parchment thickness with professional scraping

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Noble patron and his hunting retinue

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-15th century hunting illustration, likely from a Parisian atelier, exemplifies the courtly Livre de chasse tradition, echoing Gaston Phoebus’s treatise. The lavish use of ultramarine and gold leaf, together with the professional bastarda script, indicates a high-status commission. Technically, the layered pigment application with white lead highlights and underdrawn contours reveal the workshop’s mastery. The scene’s composition, centralized around the dramatic confrontation between huntsman and boar, and its naturalistic rendering of dogs and horses, reflect an increasing interest in observational realism characteristic of late Gothic illumination. Iconographically, the boar embodies both material and spiritual challenge, aligning noble prowess with moral virtue. The alternating color schemes on riders and steeds denote rank and lend rhythmic harmony, while the distant fortifications situate the hunt within a broader territorial claim. Compared to contemporary English Channel School manuscripts, this image exhibits bolder modeling and a more dynamic diagonal thrust in figure arrangement. The folio thus bridges traditional iconography of medieval bestiaries with emerging Renaissance sensibilities in spatial treatment. As both didactic tool and display piece, it reinforces aristocratic identity through martial equestrian imagery, while advancing pictorial conventions in workshop practice.
